Besides being the executive producer of D12's first two albums, ''[[Devil's Night (album)|Devil's Night]]'' and ''[[D12 World]]'', he has executive produced Obie Trice's ''[[Cheers (album)|Cheers]]'' and ''[[Second Round's on Me]]'' as well as 50 Cent's ''[[Get Rich or Die Tryin' (album)|Get Rich or Die Tryin']]'' and ''[[The Massacre]]''.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A2834-2005Mar2.html|title=Guns & Lovers: Two Sides of 50 Cent |work=Washington Post | first=Sean | last=Daly | date=March 3, 2005}}</ref> In addition, Eminem has produced songs by other famous rappers, such as [[Jadakiss]]' "Welcome To D-Block", [[Jay-Z]]'s "[[Renegade (Jay-Z song)|Renegade]]" and "Moment of Clarity" [[Lloyd Banks]]' "[[On Fire (Lloyd Banks song)|On Fire]]", "Warrior Part 2", and "[[Hands Up (Lloyd Banks song)|Hands Up]]", [[Tony Yayo]]'s "Drama Setter", [[Trick-Trick]]'s "[[Welcome 2 Detroit (song)|Welcome 2 Detroit]]", and Xzibit's "My Name" and "Don't Approach Me".<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1486416/20040416/eminem.jhtml?headlines=true|title=For The Record: Quick News On Eminem And Jadakiss, William Hung, Blink-182, Beastie Boys, The Darkness & More |publisher=MTV News}}</ref> Most of ''The Eminem Show'' was produced by Eminem himself, with co-production from longtime collaborator [[Bass Brothers|Jeff Bass]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/music/0223,christgau,35393,22.html|title=White American |publisher=[[The Village Voice]]}}</ref> He split the production with Dr. Dre on ''Encore''. In 2004, Eminem was the Executive Producer of [[Tupac Shakur|2Pac]]'s posthumous album ''[[Loyal to the Game]]'' with 2Pac's mother [[Afeni Shakur]].<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A18004-2004Dec21.html|title=Posthumous 2Pac and the Living Em |work=Washington Post | first=Sarah | last=Godfrey | date=December 22, 2004}}</ref> He produced the UK No. 1 single "[[Ghetto Gospel]]" which featured [[Elton John]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.nme.com/news/elton-john/24127|title=Elton John goes hip-hop! |work=NME |location=UK}}</ref> He has produced "The Cross" off [[Nas]]'s album ''[[God's Son]]''.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/kelis/albums/album/99319/review/6067946/gods_son|title= Album Reviews |work=Rolling Stone|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071209025905/http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/kelis/albums/album/99319/review/6067946/gods_son |archivedate =2007-12-09|deadurl=yes}}</ref> On August 15, 2006, [[Obie Trice]] released ''[[Second Round's on Me]]''. Eminem produced 8 tracks on the album. He was featured in the song "There They Go".<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002345972|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070808081415/http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002345972|archivedate=2007-08-08|title=Obie Trice Back For 'Seconds' On New CD |work=Billboard}}</ref> Eminem produced some tracks on the new Trick-Trick album, ''The Villain''. He is also featured in "Who Want It".<ref>{{cite news|last=Reid|first=Shaheem|title=Eminem Brings Weight To Trick Trick LP; Newcomer Says Slim Shady Hasn't Gotten Fat, Though|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1580372/20080125/eminem.jhtml|publisher=[[MTV News]]|date=January 28, 2008|accessdate=2008-02-01}}</ref>
With regard to the productions on his own records, Eminem is seen as having an unusual style in that rather than write to beats he typically starts with an idea of how he wants his song to be structured based on the lyrics and then creates music according to that.<ref name="hitquarters.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_MarcLabelle.html |title=Interview With Marc Labelle |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=November 28, 2005 |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref> A notable exception to this was the song "Stan", which came from an idea and scratch track produced by Mark the 45 King.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/>
===Comparisons to other artists=== As [[Asher Roth]] gained prominence being a white performer in a predominantly black musical genre, Roth has earned many comparisons to Eminem, so much so that he devoted a track on his album to the famed rapper, entitled "As I Em."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/news-and-opinion/cover-story/Asher-Roth-42983072.html?page=2&comments=1&showAll= |title=Asher Roth Is on His Way to Stardom | Cover Story | News and Opinion |publisher=Philadelphia Weekly |accessdate=2011-08-20}}</ref>
Eminem and [[Christian hip hop]] artist [[KJ-52]] were often compared to each other, as many called KJ-52 the "Christian counterpart" of Eminem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/iyf/music/bandsartists/3.29.html |title=The Christian Slim Shady? | Teens |publisher=Christianitytoday.com |date=January 3, 2001 |accessdate=2011-10-11}}</ref> One of the most notable mainstream reactions to Gospel rap was to KJ-52 and his single "Dear Slim", which was written to Eminem in an attempt reach him with the message of Christianity, though Eminem claims to be a Christian.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} The song became famous and controversial among Eminem fans when it was featured on the hit show ''[[Total Request Live]]''. KJ-52 began to receive [[hate mail]] (including death threats) from Eminem's fans, though KJ-52 claimed that the song was not intended to be disrespectful.<ref name="KJInterview">{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/music/interviews/2003/kj52-0903.html |title=ChristianMusicToday.com: KJ-52 Interview – Getting It Right |publisher=Christianitytoday.com |accessdate=2011-10-06}}</ref> This also led to the single being disparaged by [[VH1]] as No. 26 on their "Top 40 Worst Moments in Hip Hop".<ref name="VH1 Top 40 Worst Moments in Hip Hop">{{cite web|url=http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=4361045648095264170&q=thoughtquotient |title=KJ-52 – 2006 GMA Music Awards |publisher=Google |accessdate=2011-10-06}}</ref>
In 2011, rapper [[Mac Miller]] was praised by Donald Trump, who called Miller "the next Eminem" in reaction to Miller's music video "Donald Trump" reached 20 million views on YouTube. Criticism of this remark led MTV news to talk to Miller about the comment, with Miller responding "...all he meant was I’m a white rapper and I’m blowing up."<ref>{{cite web|last=Chandler|first=D.L.|title=Donald Trump Calls Mac Miller Next Eminem, Rapper Drops 'Frick Park Market'|url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2011/08/18/donald-trump-calls-mac-miller-next-eminem-rapper-drops-frick-park-market/|publisher=MTV|date=August 18, 2011}}</ref>
==Personal life==
===Family=== Eminem has been the subject of much scrutiny, both as a rapper as well as in his personal life.<ref name="criminal"/> He was married twice to Kimberly Anne Scott, whom he met in high school. Kimberly had run away from her home as a teenager, along with her sister Dawn. They moved in with Marshall and his mother when he was 15. Kim and Marshall began their on-and-off relationship in 1989, and were married in 1999. In 2000, they filed for divorce shortly after Kim's second drunk driving conviction.<ref name="MarshallMathers.com">[http://www.marshallmathers.com/index.php/know/articles/45-all-about-kim All about Kim] MarshallMathers.com. Retrieved 2011-11-01.</ref> The couple first divorced in 2001<ref name="about">[http://marriage.about.com/od/entertainmen1/p/eminem.htm Marshall (Eminem) Mathers and Kimberley Scott Marriage Profile] About.com. Retrieved 2008-07-03.</ref> but remarried in January 2006. Their second divorce was finalized in December of the same year, with the couple agreeing to share custody of their daughter, Hailie Jade Mathers (born December 25, 1995).<ref name="about"/><ref name="personal life"/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6195977.stm Eminem divorces for second time] BBC; Retrieved 2008-07-03.</ref> Hailie Mathers has often been referenced or featured on various songs by Mathers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wifc.com/blogs/post/belky/2011/mar/15/hollywood-shorts-eminems-daughter-hailie-15-surpri/ |title=Hollywood Shorts-Eminem's Daughter Hailie, 15, Is a Surprisingly Positive Tweeter – 95–5 WIFC Your No.1 Hit Music Station |publisher=Wifc.com |date=March 15, 2011 |accessdate=2011-06-14}}</ref> including "[['97 Bonnie & Clyde]]", "Hailie's Song", "[[My Dad's Gone Crazy]]", "[[Mockingbird (Eminem song)|Mockingbird]]", "[[When I'm Gone (Eminem song)|When I'm Gone]]", "[[Beautiful (Eminem song)|Beautiful]]", "[[Airplanes Pt. II]]", "[[Going Through Changes]]", and "[[You're Never Over]]".
In early 2010, Mathers responded publicly to tabloid reports of his pending reunion with Kim with a firm denial.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalledger.com/artman/publish/article_272630307.shtml |title=Eminem & Wife Reunion Denied |work=National Ledger |date=February 8, 2010 |accessdate=2010-02-10 }}</ref>
Eminem has adopted two other daughters: Alaina "Lainie" Mathers, the child of Kimberley Scott's sister,<ref name="about"/> who has been referenced by name in some songs including "[[Mockingbird (Eminem song)|Mockingbird]]", "[[Airplanes Pt. II|Airplanes Part II]]" and "[[Going Through Changes]]"; and Whitney, Scott's child from a previous relationship. Whitney is mentioned in the song "Deja Vu" as well as "Going Through Changes". Mathers is also the legal guardian of his younger half-brother, Nathan who has been mentioned in "[[Cleanin' Out My Closet]]" and "My Mom".
===Legal troubles=== In 1999, Eminem's mother sued him for around US$10 million over alleged [[slander]] about her in his lyrics regarding ''The Slim Shady LP''; she won about US$1,600 in damages in 2001.<ref>{{harvnb|Bozza|2003|p=69}}</ref>
Eminem was arrested on June 3, 2000 during an altercation at a car audio store in [[Royal Oak, Michigan]], with Douglas Dail, where he pulled out an unloaded gun and kept it pointed at the ground.<ref name="AOZ">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.the411online.com/news18.html|title=Tour tickets available for a price |publisher=The 411 Online}}</ref> The following day, in [[Warren, Michigan]], he allegedly saw his then wife, Kim, kiss bouncer John Guerrera in the parking lot of the ''Hot Rock Café'', and he assaulted him and was then arrested.<ref name="about"/><ref name="personal life"/><ref name="AOZ"/> Eminem recreated the Guerrera assault in a skit on his junior album ''[[The Eminem Show]]'' on a track called "The Kiss (Skit)." Mathers was charged with possession of a concealed weapon and assault. Mathers plead guilty to the charges and was given two years [[probation]] for both episodes.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1442656/20010410/eminem.jhtml|title=Eminem Gets Two Years' Probation In Weapon Case|publisher=MTV}}</ref>
On July 7, 2000, Eminem's then-wife, Kimberly Scott attempted suicide by slashing her wrists.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/827159.stm |title=Eminem wife's suicide bid|publisher=BBC News |date=July 10, 2000 |accessdate=2011-06-14}}</ref> Scott sued Eminem for [[defamation]] after he depicted her violent death in his song "[[Kim (song)|Kim]]".<ref name="about"/><ref name="personal life">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4882092.stm Eminem and Kim to divorce again] [[BBC]]; Retrieved 2008-07-03.</ref>
On October 26, 2000, Eminem was to perform at a concert in Toronto's [[Rogers Centre|Skydome]].<ref name = "B">{{cite news|title = Ontario wants rap star banned|first = Richard|last = Mackie|author2 = Marissa Nelson|format = newspaper|work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada |location = Toronto|date = October 26, 2000|pages = A1, A4|accessdate =2009-05-27}}</ref> However, [[Ontario]] Attorney General Jim Flaherty argued that Canada should stop Eminem at the border. "I personally don't want anyone coming to Canada who will come here and advocate violence against women," he said.<ref name = "B"/> Flaherty claims to have been "disgusted" when reading transcriptions of Eminem's song "Kill You", which includes lines like "Slut, you think I won't choke no whore/till the vocal cords don't work in her throat no more?"<ref name = "B"/> The opinion of the general public to the requests made by the province were negative. Others said the issue was one of [[free speech]]. [[Liberal Party (Canada)|Liberal]] MPP Michael Bryant suggested that the government lay [[hate crime]] charges against Eminem for the advocacy of violence against women found in his lyrics.<ref name = "B"/> In a ''[[Globe and Mail]]'' editorial, author Robert Everett-Green wrote, "Being offensive is Eminem's job description."<ref name = "A">{{cite news|title = Bad rap for a rapper|first = Robert|last = Everett-Green|format = newspaper|work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada |location = Toronto|date = October 26, 2000|page = A25|accessdate =2009-05-27}}</ref> Eminem's Toronto concert went on as planned that night.<ref name = "D">{{cite news | title = Eminem to play despite Canadian officials concerns|first = Jon|last = Zahlaway |work=LiveDaily|date = October 26, 2000|url=http://www.livedaily.com/news/2069.html|accessdate =2009-05-27}}</ref>
D'Angelo Bailey, a sanitation worker, sued Eminem in 2001 and accused him of invading his privacy by publicizing (in the song “Brain Damage”) unreasonable information that put him in a false light. Bailey admitted that he picked on Mathers but said he merely "bumped" him at school and threw a "little shove." On October 20, 2003, the charges were dismissed in court.<ref name="Fox News"/>
On June 28, 2001, Eminem was sentenced to one year probation on weapons charges that stemmed from an argument with an employee of [[Psychopathic Records]], assessing him a fine around $2,000 as well as several hours of community service.<ref>{{cite news|last=van Horn|first=Teri|title=Eminem Gets Probation|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1444843/20010628/eminem.jhtml|publisher=[[MTV News]]|date=June 28, 2001|accessdate=2008-01-30}}</ref>
On March 31, 2002, French [[jazz]] pianist [[Jacques Loussier]] filed a $10 million lawsuit against Eminem and [[Dr. Dre]], claiming the beat for "Kill You" was stolen from his song.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/1904507.stm|title=Eminem sued by jazz star |accessdate=2008-12-24 |publisher=BBC News |date=March 31, 2002}}</ref> Loussier demanded that all sales of the album be halted and any remaining copies destroyed. A trial date was set to begin in June 2004. The case was later settled.<ref>{{cite news | first = Robin | last = Finn | title = A Defender of the Controversial, and Now of Imus | date = May 25, 2007 | work=New York Times | accessdate =2010-05-25}}</ref>
On December 8, 2003, the United States Secret Service admitted it was "looking into" allegations that Eminem had threatened the President of the United States, [[George W. Bush]],<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2003/SHOWBIZ/Music/12/05/eminem.lyrics/ |publisher=CNN | title=Secret Service checks Eminem's 'dead president' lyric | date=December 5, 2003 | accessdate=2010-05-02}}</ref> after the song "We as Americans", as an unreleased bootleg, circulated with the lyrics "Fuck money, I don't rap for dead presidents. I'd rather see the president dead, it's never been said but I set precedents." The incident was later referenced in the video for his song [[Mosh (song)|"Mosh"]] as one of several news clips on a wall, along with other newspaper articles about other unfortunate incidents in Bush's career. The song eventually appeared on the album's bonus disc, where the lyrics were extensively censored.
In 2005, Eminem's aunt and uncle, Jack and Betty Schmitt, sued him, alleging that he has promised them a $350,000 house and the money to keep it up, and instead has kept it in his name and tried to evict them.<ref name="Fox News"/>
In 2007, his music publishing company, ''Eight Mile Style LLC'', together with Martin Affiliated LLC, filed suit against [[Apple Inc.]] and [[Aftermath Entertainment]] claiming Aftermath did not have the appropriate authority to negotiate a deal with Apple for digital downloads of 93 Eminem songs on Apple's [[iTunes]] service.<ref name="apple2">{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20090923/FREE/909239976# |title=Crainsdetroit.com |publisher=Crainsdetroit.com |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref><ref>"Apple, Eminem headed for trial as talks break down," Stempel, Jonathan, 2009 September 23, [http://www.reuters.com/article/internetNews/idUSTRE58M31S20090923 reuters.com]</ref> The case against Apple was settled shortly after trial began in late September 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/10/06/ap/music/main5366998.shtml |title=Eminem's Music Publisher, Apple Settle Dispute |publisher=Cbsnews.com |date=October 6, 2009 |accessdate=2010-09-12 |deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=December 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
In July 2010 the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] ruled in [[F.B.T. Productions, LLC v. Aftermath Records]] that F.B.T. Productions and Eminem were owed a royalty of 50% of the net revenue Aftermath obtained by licensing Eminem's recordings to companies like [[Apple Inc.]], [[Sprint Nextel|Sprint]], [[Nextel]], [[Cingular]], and [[T-Mobile]]. In March 2011 the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] upheld this ruling.<ref name=scotus_appeal>[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12478269983023958737&q=F.B.T.+Productions,+LLC+v.+Aftermath+Records&hl=en&as_sdt=2,5, Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.], March 21, 2011</ref>
===Drug issues=== Eminem has spoken openly about his addiction to prescription drugs, including [[Vicodin]], [[Ambien]], [[Valium]] and [[Methadone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20276424,00.html|title=Eminem Bounces Back from 20-Pill-a-Day Addiction|last=McGee|first=Tiffany|date=May 4, 2009|accessdate=2010-11-28}}</ref> His group-mate [[Proof (rapper)|Proof]] from D12 stated that Mathers "sobered up" in 2002 from drug and alcohol dependence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1452709/20020301/eminem.jhtml|title=Has Eminem Gone The Way Of Mase And MC Hammer?|publisher=[[MTV News]]|date=March 4, 2002|accessdate=2008-04-23}}</ref> However, he did turn to [[zolpidem]] (Ambien) sleeping pills for relief from sleeping troubles. This caused Mathers to cancel the European leg of the [[Anger Management Tour]] in August 2005 and eventually go into rehab for treatment for a "dependency on sleep medication".<ref name="abc"/><ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1638544.html|title=Drug of choice: Fame can be its own drug but for a select few, it's just not enough |work=Chicago Sun-Times}}</ref> In a 2009 interview with British talk-show host [[Jonathan Ross]], Mathers admitted that at the height of his addiction, he considered suicide, saying that, "I just wasn't taking care of myself, at times I wanted to just give it up."<ref name="considered1">{{cite web|url=http://www.idiomag.com/peek/81707/eminem|title=Eminem considered suicide|accessdate=2009-05-14|date=May 13, 2009|publisher=[[idiomag]]}}</ref> He also confirmed that he is now sober, commenting that, "Rap was my drug ... Then I had to resort to other things to make me feel that. Now rap's getting me high again."<ref name="considered1"/>
===Proof's death=== On April 11, 2006, Eminem’s best friend and fellow D12 member, [[Proof (rapper)|Proof]] was killed by a gunshot wound to the chest at the CCC Club by club [[Bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]] Mario Etheridge on [[8 Mile Road]] in Detroit, Michigan after fatally shooting Keith Bender, Jr. On April 19, 2006, Eminem, D12, 50 Cent, and thousands of others attended the funeral of Proof at The Fellowship Chapel, Detroit.<ref>{{cite news|title=D12, Eminem, 50 Cent and Others Attend Proof's Funeral|date=April 20, 2006|publisher=SixShot.com|url=http://www.sixshot.com/news/6031}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}}</ref> Eminem made two songs about Proof's death on his album ''[[Recovery (Eminem album)|Recovery]]'' titled "Going Through Changes" and "You're Never Over", and mentions him in songs on ''[[Relapse (Eminem album)|Relapse]]'' and ''[[Recovery (Eminem album)|Recovery]]'' ("Deja Vu", "[[Beautiful (Eminem song)|Beautiful]]", and "Cinderella Man").
==Feuds== {{more information|Eminem feuds}} {{summarize|from|Eminem feuds}}
==Controversy== Eminem was involved in many controversies over lyrics which have been perceived as being [[homophobic]]; an Australian politician attempted to ban entry for Eminem because of these lyrics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/Australia_wants_to_ban_Eminem/470469 |title=Australia wants to ban Eminem |publisher=Hollywood.com |date=July 2, 2001 |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> Eminem, however, denies that he is homophobic and defends that during his upbringing such obscene words as ''faggot'' and ''queer'' were commonly spoken as being derogatory in general and not implicitly singled towards homosexuals. During an interview with CBS ''[[60 Minutes]]'' program, gay journalist [[Anderson Cooper]] had a conversation about the issue with Eminem:<ref>{{cite news|title=EMINEM DISCUSSES HOMOPHOBIC LYRICS WITH ANDERSON COOPER|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2010/10/eminem-discusses-homophobic-lyrics-with-anderson-cooper.html|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=10 November 2010|agency=Towelroad.com}}</ref> :'''Cooper''': Some of the lyrics, like, you know, in the song "Criminal" you say "My words are like a dagger with a jagged edge, That'll stab you in the head, whether you're a fag or lez, Or the homosex, hermaph or a trans-a-vest, Pants or dress - hate fags? The answer's "yes"" :'''Eminem''': Yeah, this scene I came up in. That word was thrown around so much, you know, faggot was like thrown around constantly to each other, like in battling. :'''Cooper''': Do you not like gay people? :'''Eminem''': No, I don't have any problem with nobody. You know what I mean? I'm just like whatever.
Eminem is, in fact, a friend of gay singer [[Elton John]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news-article/john-slams-eminems-homophobic-label |title=Elton John – John Slams Eminem's Homophobic Label – Contactmusic News |publisher=Contactmusic.com |date=April 8, 2005 |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> and publicly supports gay rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/37759634/ns/today-entertainment/t/new-tolerant-eminem-supports-gay-marriage/ |title=New ‘tolerant’ Eminem supports gay marriage – Entertainment – Music |publisher=Today.msnbc.msn.com |date=June 17, 2010 |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> When asked in an interview with the ''[[New York Times]]'' about the subject of [[same-sex marriage]] being legalized in his home state of Michigan, Eminem responded, "I think if two people love each other, then what the hell? I think that everyone should have the chance to be equally miserable, if they want", explaining that his "overall look on things is a lot more mature than it used to be."<ref name="QuestionsforEm">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/20/magazine/20fob-q4-t.html?_r=1|title=Questions for Eminem – The Real Marshall Mathers|last=Solomon|first=Deborah|date=June 16, 2010|accessdate=2012-03-11|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:Eminem Shanghai graffit.jpg|thumb|300px|Eminem graffiti in [[Shanghai]], China]] Eminem is the best-selling artist of the 2000s (decade) on the US [[Nielsen SoundScan]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Montgomery |first=James |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1627833/20091208/eminem.jhtml |title=Eminem Is The Best-Selling Artist Of The Decade |work=MTV News |date=December 8, 2009 |accessdate=2010-05-21}}</ref> and has sold more than 90 million albums worldwide to date, making him one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists in the world]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.directstar.fr/video/dndxw |title=Star Story Eminem – Docs – Direct Star |publisher=Directstar.fr |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=2011-06-14}}</ref> He has totaled over 1 billion views on his music videos on his official [[Vevo]] page on YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/news/eminem-passes-1-billion-youtube-views-1005043822.story#/news/eminem-passes-1-billion-youtube-views-1005043822.story |title=Billboard.com |work=Billboard |accessdate=2011-03-16}}</ref> Eminem was ranked 83rd on ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine's list of the 100 Greatest Artists of All Time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-artists-of-all-time-19691231/eminem-19691231 |title=Rolling Stone, 100 Greatest Artists of All Time |accessdate=2012-03-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = The Immortals: The First Fifty| work=Rolling Stone Issue 946| url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5939214/the_immortals_the_first_fifty | accessdate =2008-07-08 }}</ref> He was also named the Best Rapper Alive by ''Vibe'' magazine in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|last=Reid |first=Shaheem |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1596451/20081007/eminem.jhtml |title=Eminem Is The Best Rapper Alive, According To Vibe Poll |work=Mtv |date=October 7, 2008 |accessdate=2010-09-12}}</ref> In December 2009, Eminem was named the Artist of the Decade by [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'' magazine]].<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/#/charts-decade-end/artists-of-the-decade?year=2009 Artists of the decade]</ref> In 2010, MTV Portugal ranked Eminem as the seventh biggest icon in pop music history.<ref>[http://www.mtv.pt/programas/MTV-Top-10/episodios/MTV-top-10-episode-1/video/mtv-top-10-ep-1-pop-icons-07-eminem-601963/ MTV Top 10 | Ep. 1 | Pop Icons No.07 | Eminem | MTV Top 10 – episode 1deMTV Top 10 | Vídeo | MTV Portugal]. Mtv.pt. Retrieved 2010-12-21.</ref> During 2010, Eminem's music generated 94 million streams, more than any other music artist.<ref name="BW-2010YE"/> Also according to ''Billboard'', Eminem has two of his albums among the top five highest selling albums of the 2000s (decade). In the UK, Eminem has sold over 12.5 million records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theofficialcharts.com/artist/_/eminem/ |title=EMINEM – The Official Charts Company |work=Theofficialcharts.com |accessdate=2010-06-14}}</ref> Eminem has also sold more than 33 million track downloads and 40.9 million albums in the United States alone.<ref name="BW-2010YE">{{cite web |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110106006565/en/Nielsen-Company-Billboard%E2%80%99s-2010-Music-Industry-Report |title=The Nielsen Company & Billboard's 2010 Music Industry Report |publisher=Business Wire |date=January 6, 2011 |accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref><ref name="new.music.yahoo.com">{{cite web|last=Grein |first=Paul |url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/74426/week-ending-oct-23-2011-albums-casting-crowns-not-crowned/ |title=Week Ending October 23, 2011. Albums: Casting Crowns Not Crowned | Chart Watch – Archives – Yahoo! Music |publisher=New.music.yahoo.com |date=October 26, 2011 |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> Including his work as a part of groups, Eminem has achieved ten No. 1 albums on the Billboard 200, seven solo (five studio albums, two compilations), two with D12 and one with [[Bad Meets Evil]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/17386/121335 |title= Eminem Will Score Biggest Sales Week of 2010 |work=Rolling Stone |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref> Eminem has had 13 number one singles worldwide. His albums ''[[The Eminem Show]]'', ''[[The Marshall Mathers LP]]'', and ''[[Encore (Eminem album)|Encore]]'' ranked as the 3rd, 7th, and 40th best-selling albums of the 2000–2009 decade respectively by ''Billboard'' magazine.<ref name="billboard.com">[http://www.billboard.com/#/charts-decade-end/billboard-200-albums?year=2009 Billboard 200 albums], Billboard.com</ref><ref>[http://www.billboard.com/#/charts-decade-end/billboard-200-albums?year=2009&begin=21&order=position Billboard 200 albums], Billboard.com</ref> In August 2011 Eminem was named "The King of Hip-Hop" by ''Rolling Stone''.<ref name="rollingstone1"/> The magazine looked at solo rappers who released music between 2009 and the first half of 2011 by analizing their album sales, rankings on the R&B/hip-hop and rap charts, YouTube views, social media, concert grosses, industry awards and critics' ratings,<ref name="rollingstone1"/> and the data accumulated named Eminem the king of the time period.
Eminem's second major label studio album, ''[[The Marshall Mathers LP]]'', became the fastest-selling solo album in United States history.<ref name="MMLP">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-04-23 |url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5923810/eminem_bounces_britney_from_top_spot|title=Eminem Bounces Britney From Top Spot |work=Rolling Stone|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080401120550/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5923810/eminem_bounces_britney_from_top_spot |archivedate =2008-04-01|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The album has been ranked as one of the greatest hip hop albums of all time by such magazines as ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', and ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]''.<ref>Magazines that have ranked ''[[The Marshall Mathers LP]]'' as one of the greatest hip hop albums of all time: *{{cite web |url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5938174/the_rs_500_greatest_albums_of_all_time/4|title=The RS 500 Greatest Albums of All Time: Rolling Stone|accessdate=2008-12-21|work=Rolling Stone|date=November 18, 2003}}{{dead link|date=August 2011}} *{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/2006/100albums/index.html|title= The All-TIME 100 Albums|accessdate=2008-12-21|work= TIME|date=November 13, 2006}} *{{cite journal | author=XXL |authorlink=XXL (magazine) |title=Retrospective: XXL Albums |journal= XXL Magazine, December 2007 issue |year=2007 }} *{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1438949/20010201/eminem.jhtml|title=Gay Activist Group Plans Pre-Grammy Eminem Protest|accessdate=2008-12-21 |work=MTV|date=February 1, 2001}} </ref> ''Rolling Stone'' placed the album at number seven on its list of the best albums of the 2000s (decade).<ref name="rollingstone.com">{{cite web|author=Nigel D. |url=http://realtalkny.uproxx.com/2009/12/topic/topic/discussions/rolling-stones-top-100-albums-of-the-decade/ |title=Rolling Stones Top 100 Albums Of The Decade | RealTalkNY |publisher=Realtalkny.uproxx.com |date=December 10, 2009 |accessdate=2011-08-20}}</ref> The album's third single, "[[Stan (song)|Stan]]", is one of Eminem's most critically acclaimed songs, having been ranked by [[About.com]] as Eminem's best song and referred to by [[Pitchfork Media]] as "a cultural milestone".<ref>[http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/17456/Eminem_Curtain_Call_The_Hits Pitchfork: Album Reviews: Eminem: Curtain Call: The Hits]. Pitchforkmedia.com (2005-12-05). Retrieved 2011-01-19.</ref> In 2005, Eminem was ranked 79th on the [[VH1]] 100 Greatest Artists of All-Time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/michael-jackson-the-beatles-bob-dylan-led-zeppelin-and-the-rolling-stones-top-vh1s-100-greatest-music-artists-of-all-time-list-101454764.html |title=Michael Jackson, the Beatles, Bob Dylan, Led Zeppelin and the Rolling Stones Top... – NEW YORK, August 25 /PRNewswire/ |location=New York |publisher=Prnewswire.com |date=August 25, 2010 |accessdate=2010-10-26}}</ref>

==Awards and nominations== {{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Eminem}} Eminem has thirteen [[Grammy Awards]]. He has been praised for having "verbal energy", high quality of lyricism and has been ranked number nine on MTV's list of ''The Greatest MCs of All Time''.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3033614.stm Seamus Heaney praises Eminem]. BBC. Retrieved 2007-07-31.</ref><ref name="mtv top10">[http://www.mtv.com/bands/h/hip_hop_week/2006/emcees/index3.jhtml The Greatest MCs of All Time] ''MTV''. Retrieved 2008-07-08.</ref> In 2003 he was listed as number thirteen on MTV's 22 Greatest Voices in Music<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.listology.com/content_show.cfm/content_id.19522 |title=Listology: MTV's 22 Greatest Voices in Music |publisher=Listology.com |accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> and number 82 on ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s "The Immortals".<ref name="The Immortals: Rolling Stone"/> In 2008, the readers of [[Vibe (magazine)|''Vibe Magazine'']] voted him "The Best Rapper Alive".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rapbasement.com/eminem/100708-vibe-magazine-voters-name-eminem-the-best-rapper-alive.html |title=Eminem Is The Best Rapper Alive | Eminem | Rap Basement|publisher=Rapbasement.com |accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> He was also named "Best Rapper Ever" in a poll conducted by music fans on the ''Vibe'' website.
Ironically, "[[The Real Slim Shady]]", one of the songs from his second Grammy-winning album, ''[[The Marshall Mathers LP]]'', slammed the Grammy Awards in its second verse, and stated the opinion that negative feelings about his material would keep him from ever winning one.
